teacher.objective: Students understand that irrational numbers can be approximated to rational numbers. Students can roughly estimate where to place irrational numbers on a number line diagram.
hints: You want to make sure that they have a good understanding of what rational and irrational numbers are
You want to teach them to approximate irrational numbers to 2 decimal places for this class and make it clear that the more decimal places, the more precise an approximation.
You want to teach them that irrational numbers should be graphed on the number line about where their approximation would be graphed, but the label should still be the irrational number
Example approximation: The approximation of pi that the students should know is 3.14. The approximation of sqrt(2) is 1.41
You want to make sure that they can label the graph with the irrational number and not an approximation

students.profile:
I know that rational numbers are real numbers (numbers that do not involve sqrt(-1)) that can be expressed as a fraction or ratio of two integers, as long as the denominator is non-zero.  I know that irrational numbers are real numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers. 
I know that irrational numbers can be approximated to rational numbers, but I’m not sure exactly when to stop. I mean, they’re endless and never repeat. I usually just write out all the ones I see on a calculator screen. So, I guess something like 10 digits is good enough.
I know from learning rational numbers last year that 530 is a better approximation of 532 than 500 is. It’s more precise. I guess the more digits you have, the more precise it would be, and approximations of irrational numbers probably work about the same way.
I learned how to graph all rational numbers last year, and I can do that well. I think it’s impossible to graph an irrational number on a number line because it’s never ending. Sure, ⅓ can be graphed even though it’s never ending, but it repeats at some point and is a rational number. Irrational numbers like pi or sqrt(2) are weird, and I don’t think you can graph them.

I know that rational numbers are real numbers that can be expressed as a fraction or ratio of two integers, as long as the denominator is non-zero.  I know that irrational numbers are real numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers. 
I know that irrational numbers can be approximated to rational numbers, and my teacher has taught me that we should approximate to 2 decimal places. The approximation of sqrt(13) is 3.61 and the approximation of pi is 3.14. 
I know we can approximate to more than 2 decimal places to be more precise, but 2 decimal places is good enough.

questions.question: Graphing pi is possible and would be labeled with pi, not 3.14
1.414 is a more precise approximation of sqrt(2) than 1.41
